DOC.TEXT: The stock market lost more ground today, extending the decline that began late last week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 14.08 on Friday, dropped another 5.33 to 2,734.22 by noontime today on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 491 up, 866 down and 512 unchanged. Brokers said traders remained uneasy about the outlook for real-estate finance and regional bank stocks after the Bank of New England on Friday announced projected increases in its loan-loss reserve and non-performing assets. In the past couple of weeks, Wall Street has been devoting increased concern to the soft real estate market in many parts of the country and the problems real-estate debt might pose should prices of properties lag for an extended period. Bank of New England shares led the active list, down 1 at 8 on the heels of a 3]-point drop Friday. Among other actively traded banking and mortgage issues, Bank of Boston fell | to 16{ and Federal National Mortgage was down 2{ at 31\. Otherwise, analysts said hopes persisted that stocks could overcome their recent hesitancy and gain ground in the next few weeks, aided by the lifting of pressures from yearend tax selling. Marriott rose 1[ to 35}. The company announced a restructuring plan that calls for its departure from the fast-food and family restaurant business and the buyback of an additional 10 million of its shares. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped .67 to 192.78. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 1.50 at 374.00. Volume on the Big Board came to 74.84 million shares at noontime.
